Articles.Content:
The Great Game was essentially a large strategy board game used to make up the back story of the pen-and-paper RPG "2300 AD". It's been described as somewhat like a free-form civ game.

If anyone else would be interested in participating in such a project, I could set up a website and stuff for it.

A website is up:

http://kerbalgreatgame.webs.com/

webs.com because both I'm an idiot and if it was hosted on my own computer the website would go down every night.

Edited September 12, 2013 by Holo

I'm bumping this, is anyone interested? Also, to avoid breaking rule 2.3a, here is nyrath's excellent explanation of what the Great Game was.

There was a (sadly defunct) game company called Game Designer's Workshop. For their hard-SF role playing game 2300 AD, they needed a future history. So they simulated it with a game, the so-called "Great Game." A team of expert players was each assigned one nation and the game was played until the time reached 2300 AD. The events that occurred were recorded, and became the future history.

This is the sort of thing I'm interested in, but how would you envision it working in KSP?

-Will

This is the sort of thing I'm interested in, but how would you envision it working in KSP?

-Will

Nah, I do it often. Not all the time. Usually it's when I don't wish to really remain active in the thread, but am dumping important or relevant information in one post. Or, I don't just add it to my signature because it's more genuine if one types it out every time. More sincere if you will. I also sign as "M5K" so it's not necessarily my name, but what many people call me. I dunno, it's just a thing. A style of posting.

Anyhow, back on topic guys please and thank you, this is about making an RPG in KSP, not about posting preferences. c:

-M5K

Okay, Off topic but this infuriates me. Why sign your name after posts? we know who you are by the user name to the left of the screen, and you can add a signature if you feel you must have it in a section SPECIFICALLY for signatures

Because I consider it polite to sign my real name and not just leave my forum login as the only means of identification. It's a long-time habit of mine. I have to admit I'm slightly taken aback; I've been doing this across many forums and mailing lists for well over a decade and this is the VERY FIRST time someone has complained about it.

But to get back on topic, yes, I'd like to hear about the proposed rules system for a 'great game'. I'm pretty familiar with the AD2300 setting, but IIRC the creators never published their own 'great game' rules anywhere.

-Will

Edited September 12, 2013 by Holo

Thread drift is an amazing thing.

I loved the 2300AD setting (I actually bought the first incarnation, Traveller: 2300). The setting was awesome. The rules were crap. At one point I wrote a set of conversion rules to use the setting with GURPS, but I never got around to running a campaign in it. Star Cruiser (the space combat game for 2300AD) was one of the best space combat games ever made, played the heck out of it. It still heavily influences my thoughts on space combat.

That said, I think it would be difficult to run a Great Game in KSP right now, just because we know so little about Kerbals. We know nothing about their national identities. We don't even know if they have any national identities. They may have a single world government. They may be a hive mind, for all we know. Even if they aren't all that alien (just humans in short green bodies) you still may end up writing a whole lot of stuff that will get overwritten by canon at a later date. You would have to start your Great Game in the Kerbal equivalent of the Early Bronze Age. What you really need to do is create a map of Kerbin for Civilization IV and play out their history there. (Civilization V sucked, IMHO.) I think I have a new project for the weekend....

That said, I think it would be difficult to run a Great Game in KSP right now, just because we know so little about Kerbals. We know nothing about their national identities. We don't even know if they have any national identities. They may have a single world government. They may be a hive mind, for all we know. Even if they aren't all that alien (just humans in short green bodies) you still may end up writing a whole lot of stuff that will get overwritten by canon at a later date. You would have to start your Great Game in the Kerbal equivalent of the Early Bronze Age. What you really need to do is create a map of Kerbin for Civilization IV and play out their history there. (Civilization V sucked, IMHO.) I think I have a new project for the weekend....

I'm thinking that rather than have one 300-year game and everything ends forever (and probably moves to a tripod domain, since all the dead websites seem to be there for some reason), there could be multiple great games running in series or even in parallel. That way, even if canon overwrites it there'll still be new games being run with new information.

I love your idea of running it in Civ IV. If you end up doing it, I'd love to see the results and the different nations could be used in the Game. For now, the nations existing could be player-made based on some kind of space race/kold war scenario.

It doesn't matter whether the Kerbals have national identities or not, I'll just veto that part in favour of an interesting Game.

-Thomas
